answers.a: Primarily to make industrial resins, plastics, and disinfectants; as a food additive (E240) it was historically used as a preservative but is not permitted in the EU or US due to safety concerns.
It has a strong, sharp, pungent (antiseptic) odor that is irritating and noticeable even at very low concentrations.
Yes—it's acutely irritating/toxic and is classified as a known human carcinogen; it's not allowed as a food additive, though small amounts naturally present in foods are rapidly metabolized.

answers.q: what does formaldehyde do to the body
answers.a: It reacts with tissues (proteins and DNA), causing eye, nose, and throat irritation and, at high doses, chemical burns if ingested; chronic inhalation increases certain cancer risks, though the body also produces and quickly metabolizes small amounts to formate and CO2.

answers.q: does fireball have formaldehyde in it
answers.a: No—Fireball does not contain added formaldehyde; a past European issue concerned propylene glycol, not formaldehyde.
